content.content: Disclaimer: This is my personal stance and does not represent PECU views. Read the final piece: Aggressive Growth Strategy. In my previous piece I tried explaining why we should grow Surplus Buffer and how it will fuel revenue growth. Now, I want to argue why we should stop the burn entirely for years to come. Keep in mind I am not arguing that MKR burn should stop forever however, I believe that burning MKR before we absolutely dominate the stablecoin market is very shortsighted.  Quick look at the history MakerDAO has been burning MKR for years now. I want to take a closer look at some of these periods and see the effect that burn caused on MKR price. For the lack of better tools, we will use mkrburn.com as the source.  A year in flames - 03.2019 - 03.2020 During this period, MCD constantly burned MKR. It burned almost 14k MKR (1.4% of the whole supply) in a year. One would expect that such burn pressure would do wonders to MKR price. Unfortunately, MKR price couldn’t care less and stayed relatively flat at around $550.  1354×836 54.4 KB   1322×858 44.2 KB  This period of time was ended by Black Thursday - when the system suffered a loss of about 6M DAI. At that time, Surplus Buffer size was only 500k DAI and was not enough to cover the losses, so flop actions were started and new MKR was printed. This was a disaster for MKR price as it fell to as low as $220. To cover losses, 20k MKR was minted, not only wiping out the whole year of burn but also increasing MKR total supply 5k above 1M. We can learn a few things from this event:  MKR burn of around 1% yearly didn’t have any effect on the price, Flop actions have a disastrous effect on MKR price,  The short-sightedness of MKR holders was a direct cause for flop actions - if revenues would be funneled to increase surplus buffer instead, it would be big enough to cover the losses (it would be around $7M),   A short period of massive burn - Jan 2022  838×840 21.9 KB   1266×856 37.4 KB  In the recent market pullback, liquidations generated $20M surplus that was later spent on flap auctions. This caused a short increase in ETH/MKR ratio. What we can learn:  Burn works! …but has to be massive    Why most of the time, doesn’t burn work as advertised? The buy pressure caused by burning ~1% of total supply yearly is just too small to cause a supply crunch anytime soon. To see immediate burn effects we would need to burn huge amounts of MKR (few % of supply) every year. For now, protocol revenue is too small to generate big buy pressure at the current MKR price. I would argue that market forces caused by “Threat Of Burn”™ are enough to maintain the price floor ie. a huge % burn over long periods of time will never happen because the price will increase even if no MKR is burned. Finally, if our goal is to take MKR off the market, there might be better models like vested escrowed (ve). In the future, when we are ready to burn again I’d probably opt for a hybrid solution (burn + ve) but this is a topic for another discussion…  If not burn, then what? As mentioned in my previous post, I believe that MakerDAO should refocus on aggressive growth. The easiest way to do that is to grow Surplus Buffer. Then, invest in new ways of making money while avoiding the risk of flop auctions. Right now we are facing a DAI supply crisis but once we fix it, we will need to use our cash flows to help DAI dominate the stablecoin market. DSR, cashbacks and increasing the real world DAI adoption – it all requires a lot of funds. Finally, flap auctions need some work. The current implementation is far from efficient, which causes spreads. Also just enabling small burn (via lerp) will result in a huge MKR burn in case of unexpected inflows (for example revenue from auctions). Redoing tekenomics is also a big endeavour that will keep PECU busy for months. Prioritising Surplus Buffer growth helps DAO to use engineering resources to increase revenues rather than rent-seeking.  MKR price speculation Does it mean that we should prepare for seeing MKR $1500 apiece for years to come until we revamp tokenonimics or re-enable burn? Quite the contrary. Every asset can be valued based on its fundamentals or based on its expected future growth ie. speculative value. I believe that MKR token is currently priced solely on its fundamentals. With a P/E ratio of around 15, MKR is priced like a well-established corporation that has days of explosive growth behind itself. We suffer from close to 0 speculative premium. I believe that refocus on growth is exactly what will make MKR price more speculative. The burn signals that the DAO doesn’t have any better idea on how to reinvest its revenue and basically pays back the dividend to their investors. There is a very good reason why AMZN never paid out any dividends and yet is one of the most valued companies in the world.  1600×320 126 KB  Furthermore, as mentioned before, in a scenario when DAO’s revenue 10x but price stays still, just a threat of (massive) burn should be enough to increase price and hence such scenario should never occur.  Conclusions I believe that internal consensus around the burn is one of the most critical topics that MakerDAO should achieve. Avoiding MKR burn shows a clear focus on long-term dominance in the DeFi space. I can’t wait for the future when I will be able to pay in DAI for my groceries and enjoy MKR deflation at the same time. However, I am worried that we will never see that future if we burn through our revenue now.

content.content: If you want to invest to grow aggressively, then spend your money on projects that tokenholders clearly understand and perceive to have future value.  The fact that we have positive earnings right now means that there is not an abundance of ideas that would lead to such aggressive growth in the eyes of the entire community.  If you want to compare to Amazon, you also have to recognize that Amazon had consistent revenue growth and cash flow that was completely reinvested into business operations.  It was not invested in a large cash balance that sat there growing.  Many businesses that have clear growth paths actually borrow as much as they can and investors are ok with it because they see the growth path and agree with borrowing even if it often means their shares are diluted. Maker does continue to grow but it’s hard to pinpoint whether this growth is coming as a byproduct of crypto in general growing or from core unit accomplishments. If you use cash flow to burn, I know what I’m getting and I know it’s fair.  If you throw the money into the buffer, I have to trust that you are going to use that money wisely and without any specific proposals or roadmap, I can only go by track record.  If you tell me what you’re going to do with the money, I can decide whether I think I agree with these investments and either invest or not invest.  So I’m not advocating throwing money around wastefully.  I’m just saying maybe the issue is that we don’t have have enough ideas on how to better use the money.  And if there are ideas out there, they aren’t clearly understood especially in the sense of how they might drive growth.

content.content: This is a special situation not analogous to a startup company collecting profits or Amazon trying to grow. That is because the shares are actually a financial backstop. The market cap of MKR is in large part the security of the system. In exchange for the risk of sudden inflation, MKR holders need to be paid. What MKR holders earn is revenue, not profit. What if an excessive portion of MKR value is because there are so few dividend earning blue chips in crypto? What if a large portion of demand for DAI is the legitimacy and security afforded by having a high MKR market cap? Paying MKR holders was an original required part of the MakerDAO system, because in theory no one would want to hold something that could be inflated and had no other value proposition. MKR holders are insurers that need revenue in exchange for risking capital. Sure you can argue its a dividend earning share of a bank…but its much more of a share of an insurance fund than a share of a company. The idea that a governance power once granted will be taken away in the future and turned into dividends is a weak assumption given human nature. Once you normalize a lack of revenue for people that secure the system it could be surprisingly hard to convince those with a budget to vote to give it up. So in addition to the ‘its a required part of the system’ argument, I also request consideration that it is a systemic risk to normalize removal of revenue for MKR holders because it could be difficult or impossible to undo because of incentive incompatibility.
